block.p: In case you didn't know it, skiers, you are one group that ought to be thinking about global warming.

That, in part, forms the basis of a marketing theme for a new ski model by Lunatic Fringe, a division of K2 Skis. Lunatick Fringe says it will donate 5 percent of the net wholesale price of each pair of skis sold to three groups supporting the preservation of the world's rain forests and indigenous people: Rainforest Action Network, Cultural Survival and Africa NGO Environment Network. (Suggested retail price of the skis is $535.)
In case you didn't know it, skiers, you are one group that ought to be thinking about global warming.

That, in part, forms the basis of a marketing theme for a new ski model by Lunatic Fringe, a division of K2 Skis. Lunatick Fringe says it will donate 5 percent of the net wholesale price of each pair of skis sold to three groups supporting the preservation of the world's rain forests and indigenous people: Rainforest Action Network, Cultural Survival and Africa NGO Environment Network. (Suggested retail price of the skis is $535.)
So why aim the environmental message at skiers? "If the world gets hot, there's no snow," said Tim Petrick, the vice president and general manager of Lunatic Fringe.

The new model, Panther Dream, takes its name from a children's book written by BOB WEIR, lead singer and guitarist for the Grateful Dead, and WENDY WEIR, his sister: "Panther Dream: A Story of the African Rainforest." The model's logo borrows elements from the Grateful Dead's logo (a human skull with a lightning bolt running through it). In return for use of the band's name and its logo, the band's board agreed to donate its 7 percent royalty from ski sales to the three environmental organizations.
